section.docs:
Deals represent financial interactions between contacts. A user is in charge of each deal. Deals go through these states:
1. Pending 2. Closed 3. Paid 4. Rejected
Deals may also have todos, comments, and associated attachments. They are optionally associated with a campaign.
They also have embed line items to create an invoice style structure that can eventually be handed off to fullfillment/accounting.

section.title: Routes & Permission
section.docs:
* `POST /deals`: All users * `GET /deals`: All users according to scoping rules * `GET /deals/:id`: All users according scoping rules * `PUT /deals/:id`: Managing the deal or God * `DELETE /deals/:id`: Managing the deal or God
### Scoping You can read deals you have access to. You can have access the following ways:
1. You are managing the deal 2. You are following the deal 3. The deal is public 4. You are a god

section.title: Format
section.docs:
description
Required
Long form text describing this deal
close_by
Required
The date the deal should close by.
state
Required
One of the following: pending, closed, paid, rejected
Default: pending
public
This is inherited from the account unless otherwise specified.
line_itmes
name
Required
quantity
Required
Positive integers only.
price
Required
The price of one individual unit. This is NOT the total cost.
currency
Required
See the supported currencies section
product
The ID of an associated product. If the price and currency are not specified and the product is, then these values will be filled in using the product. Specifying a product is not required.
contact
Required
ID of associated contact
user
Required
ID of the user managing this deal
todos
IDs of all the todos
comments
All comment object. See comment section.
products
IDs of all products referenced by line items
activities
ID's of all the activities in the feed
### Specifying Assocations You can change the `user` and `contact` associations by passing a `user_id` or `contact_id` attribute.

section.title: Nested Line Items
section.docs:
Line items are nested inside the deal. There are no routes to directly mainpulate individual items, so they must be managed through the deal. You can created, update, or delete items through the `line_items_attributes` attribute. It takes an array of line items objects.
If you pass an `id` then that record will be updated. If you do not pass an `id` a new record will be created. If you pass an `id` and a `_delete` the record will be deleted.
A deal will automatically be assigned to you if you don't specify the `user_id`.
